messages.message:
5 dead in 'exceptionally' strong storm in HoustonAt least five people were killed when a powerful wind storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the "exceptionally" strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
The statement also said President Biden had directed the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) "to coordinate Federal recovery operations in the affected areas."
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

(HOUSTON) — At least five people were killed when a powerful storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the “exceptionally” strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
Houston schools closed on Friday and more than 600,000 customers remain without power.
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

Getty Images - STOCK(HOUSTON) -- At least five people were killed when a powerful storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
The winds were so powerful, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said they were comparable to Hurricane Alicia in 1983.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the "exceptionally" strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

CNN —Fifty people were killed and dozens are missing after heavy rains and flooding in Afghanistan’s province of Ghor on Friday, according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugees.
The Ministry said in a post on X on Saturday that 2,000 homes had been completely destroyed and up to 4,000 partially destroyed by recent flooding.
Hundreds of people have been killed by flash flooding in Afghanistan over the past several weeks, according to the UN.
Areas in northern Afghanistan have been ravaged by the heavy floods, including the provinces of Ghor, Badakhshan, Baghlan, and Herat.
In April, unseasonal rainfall and floods killed more than 100 people in Afghanistan and Pakistan, according to authorities.

BC Wildfire Service operations director says British Columbians have heard the warningsBC Wildfire Service’s operations director says the province will continue to monitor the need for a campfire ban, but there isn’t plan for one just yet.
They are very familiar with the conditions that we face and they are being more careful.”With the recent rainfall and current temperatures, he said B.C.
doesn’t need to implement a campfire ban yet.
But BC Wildfire Service will continue to monitor and “implement one as quickly as we need to.”In a series of tweets after the update, BC Wildfire Service said human-caused fires are a real concern in B.C., accounting for about 40 per cent of all wildfires in the province.
The majority of those are in the Prince George Fire Centre – the largest region – in northeastern B.C.

“Thankfully, our worst fears have not materialized, but I want to be extremely clear — we are not out of the woods,” Bowinn Ma.
“The conditions are really tough…and we are not expecting more rain.”READ MORE: Holdover wildfires slumbering through the winter increasing B.C.
wildfire inflicts ‘some structural damage’ in Fort NelsonThe Patry Creek and Parker Lake fires remain B.C.’s two wildfires of note.
The Patry Creek fire is a holdover fire from 2023, meaning it continued to smolder underground during the winter.
Category 2 and 3 includes backyard and industrial burning, along with fireworks, sky lanterns and binary exploding targets.

“Don’t overdo yourself during the cleanup process,” the weather service’s Houston office said in a post on the social platform X.
In addition to the heat, the Houston area could face poor air quality during the weekend.
Hundreds of thousands remain without powerThe widespread destruction of Thursday's storms brought much of Houston to a standstill.
School districts in the Houston area canceled classes Friday for more than 400,000 students and government offices were closed.
“It felt terrifying.”State and federal recovery assistance on the wayIn light of the storm damage, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo and Whitmire both signed disaster declarations, paving the way for state and federal storm recovery assistance.

A man stands in the mud after a flash flood in Baghlan, Afghanistan, on May 11, 2024.
File Photo by Samiullah Popal/EPA-EFEMay 18 (UPI) -- Flash floods triggered by heavy rain killed 50 people Friday in Afghanistan's Ghor province, government officials said.
The floods also destroyed hundreds of hectares of farm land, hundreds of bridges and killed thousands of cattle, the ministry said.
More than 100 people and over 600 animals died in April from flash floods in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
The disaster was followed by a string of summer flash floods that killed over 30 people.

KABUL, May 19, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryabprovince in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in thelatest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night"resulted in human and financial losses," Asmatullah Muradi, spokesman forthe Faryab governor, said in a statement.
"Due to the floods 66 people were killed," he said, adding that at least fivepeople were injured and others were still missing.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people werekilled in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Just over a week ago, more than 300 people were killed in flash flooding innorthern Baghlan province, according to the UN World Food Programme andTaliban officials.

Fresh floods kill 66 in northern Afghanistan: provincial officialKabul, May 19 (AFP) May 19, 2024Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in the latest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Heavy floods in multiple districts of Faryab province on Saturday night "resulted in human and financial losses," Asmatullah Muradi, spokesman for the Faryab governor, said in a statement.
"Due to the floods 66 people were killed," he said, adding that at least five people were injured and others were still missing.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Just over a week ago, more than 300 people were killed in flash flooding in northern Baghlan province, according to the UN World Food Programme and Taliban officials.

Fresh floods kill 66 in northern AfghanistanKabul, May 19 (AFP) May 19, 2024Fresh floods killed 66 people in Faryab province in northern Afghanistan, a provincial official said Sunday, in the latest deadly flooding to hit the country.
Hundreds of people have died in separate flash floods this month that have also swamped farmland in a country where 80 percent of the population depends on agriculture to survive.
The floods came a day after provincial police said more than 50 people were killed in flash flooding in the western province of Ghor.
Residents in Baghlan, Ghor, Faryab and other affected regions found themselves without shelter, stripped of their homes and livelihoods.
Spring floods are not uncommon in Afghanistan, a country of more than 40 million people, but above-average rainfall this year has sparked devastating flash flooding.

— The Northern Rockies Regional Municipality in British Columbia says four homes have been lost in a wildfire that forced the evacuation of Fort Nelson more than a week ago.

Climate change is likely fueling a surge in extreme weather events across the planet.
So far, 2024 has been a particularly bad for extreme weather, according to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), with droughts, extreme heat, and floods causing severe damage to health and livelihoods.
"Almost every region in the world saw extreme weather and climate events of different natures," WMO climate expert Alvaro Silva told DW.
What extreme weather is caused by climate change and what isn't?
The damage caused by extreme weather depends on the vulnerability of the population.

messages.message:
19 May 2024 5:40 PMThe next severe weather system is developing with impacts expected across the Plains and Midwest Sunday through Tuesday.
May is the busiest month of the year for severe weather, with most storms setting up over the Great Plains of Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and northern Texas.
Already, 2024 has been one of the busiest severe weather seasons with the second-most tornadoes on record to date (2011 still holds the record).
On Sunday, a MODERATE risk (level 4 out of 5) has been issued for portions of Kansas, while the larger risk for more isolated severe storms stretches from Texas to North Dakota.
Stay with WeatherNation for the latest storm timing and threats ahead of the severe weather threat.
